title: EE656: Robotics & Control
text:
---
title: "Homework"
format: html
toc: true
---

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
## Submission
Homework is due by **11:59 PM (Asia/Riyadh)** unless stated otherwise.  
Submit via Gradescope (link/code will be posted when available).
:::

---

## Assignments

| Assignment | Release | Due | Files |
|---|---:|---:|---|
| **HW 1** | TBA | TBA | ‚Äî |
| **HW 2** | TBA | TBA | ‚Äî |
| **HW 3** | TBA | TBA | ‚Äî |

::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Quick checklist (submission)
- Submit **one PDF** (clear scans, high contrast).
- Start **each question on a new page** (recommended).
- If asked to submit code, include it in the PDF **or** as a separate file as instructed.
- Make sure your work is **readable**. Illegible submissions may lose points.
:::

---

## Policies

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### Late days
You have **6 late days** total, with a maximum of **2 late days per assignment**.  
Each late day is a **24-hour extension** (e.g., Wed 11:59 PM ‚Üí Thu 11:59 PM = 1 late day).  
No credit is given after **48 hours** past the deadline, or after late days are exhausted.
:::

::: {.accordion}
::: {.accordion-item}
### Collaboration policy and honor code
Homework must be completed **individually**.  
You may discuss concepts and approaches at a high level, but your submitted work must be entirely your own.

- Copying any part of another student‚Äôs solution is not allowed.
- Copying code or derivations is not allowed.

Small snippets of publicly available code (e.g., StackOverflow) may be used **only if properly attributed**, and only when permitted by the homework instructions.
:::

::: {.accordion-item}
### Generative AI tools policy
Unless explicitly permitted by the instructor for a specific assignment, the use of generative AI tools for any part of your homework is **not allowed** and will be treated as plagiarism.
:::

::: {.accordion-item}
### Regrade policy
Regrade requests are submitted through Gradescope. Include a clear explanation of the grading error.

- Deadline: within **1 week** of receiving your grade, by **11:59 PM**.
- We may regrade the entire assignment (your score may go **up or down**).

**Legitimate requests**
- Points were added incorrectly.
- The answer exists but was on a different page.
- The grader claims a specific case fails, but your implementation works for that case.

**Illegitimate requests**
- Disagreeing with the rubric / asking for more partial credit without an error.
- ‚ÄúMy solution wasn‚Äôt clear, but what I meant was correct.‚Äù
:::
:::

title: Course Policy
text:
Academic integrity and collaboration






WarningWhat is allowed vs not allowed



‚úÖ Allowed - Discussing concepts and approaches at a high level with classmates - Studying together and comparing understanding without sharing written solutions - Using course notes and posted examples
‚ùå Not allowed - Copying any part of another student‚Äôs written solution - Copying code, derivations, or calculations (even if you ‚Äúunderstand it‚Äù) - Submitting work that is not fully your own


If you collaborate, your submitted work must be written independently and reflect your own understanding.

title: EE656: Robotics & Control
text:
---
title: "Project"
format: html
toc: true
---

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
## EE656 Course Project
The project is a major part of the course and is designed to develop practical skill in **robot modeling and control**.
You will choose a topic, implement/validate a method, and communicate results in a short technical report and presentation.
:::

---

## Overview

### Goal
Build and evaluate a robotics/control solution that connects course theory to a realistic problem.

**Typical project directions**
- Modeling + control of a manipulator (joint-space control, computed torque, gravity compensation)
- Kinematics/IK with constraints and singularity handling
- Trajectory generation and tracking performance comparison
- Dynamics identification or parameter sensitivity analysis
- Task-space control concepts (if covered/time-permitting)

::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### Recommended scope
A strong project is **small but complete**: clear problem statement ‚Üí method ‚Üí implementation ‚Üí evaluation ‚Üí conclusions.
:::

---

## Team rules

- Teams of **1‚Äì3 students** (unless announced otherwise).
- Everyone must contribute to implementation and writing.
- You may use simulation environments and public libraries, but you must **cite** external resources and clearly state what you reused.

---

## Deliverables

| Deliverable | What to submit | Notes |
|---|---|---|
| **Proposal** | 1‚Äì2 pages PDF | problem, approach, expected results, tools, timeline |
| **Checkpoint** | short update (slides or memo) | what works, what doesn‚Äôt, next steps |
| **Final report** | 6‚Äì10 pages PDF | conference-style writing with figures and results |
| **Presentation / demo** | slides + (optional) short video | 8‚Äì12 minutes typical |

::: {.callout-important appearance="minimal"}
### Report quality expectations
Your report should include: **problem statement**, **method**, **implementation details**, **results**, and **discussion**.
Plots must be labeled and readable; claims must be supported by results.
:::

---

## Milestones (template)

Dates will be posted on the Schedule page. This is the typical flow:

- **Week 2‚Äì3:** topic selection + team formation
- **Week 4:** proposal due
- **Week 7‚Äì8:** checkpoint / early results
- **Final weeks:** final report + presentation/demo

---

## Evaluation rubric (high level)

| Category | Weight | What we look for |
|---|---:|---|
| **Technical correctness** | 35% | correct formulation, sound method, correct implementation |
| **Results & evaluation** | 30% | meaningful experiments, clear comparisons, insights |
| **Clarity & communication** | 20% | well-structured report, readable figures, clear writing |
| **Originality & ambition** | 15% | thoughtful problem choice, extensions beyond baseline |

---

## Topic ideas (starter list)

- Compare **PD vs computed-torque** on a 2-link arm (tracking + robustness tests)
- Study **IK methods** (Jacobian transpose vs pseudoinverse vs damped least squares)
- Analyze **singularities** and mitigation strategies in task-space motion
- Trajectory design: compare **cubic vs quintic** polynomials for smoothness and tracking
- Add constraints: joint limits, velocity limits, simple obstacle avoidance

---

## Academic integrity

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
You may collaborate within your team, but the final submission must reflect your team‚Äôs own work.
All external resources (code, figures, ideas) must be **cited**.
:::

---

## FAQ

**Do we need hardware?**  
No‚Äîsimulation-only projects are acceptable and often recommended.

**Can we reuse code?**  
Yes, but cite it and clearly state what you implemented vs reused.

**What if our results are negative?**  
That‚Äôs okay. A good project can show what didn‚Äôt work and why, as long as the evaluation is thoughtful.

title: EE656: Robotics & Control
text:
---
title: "Homework Policies"
format: html
toc: true
---

::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
## Homework Policies (EE656)
This page contains homework rules and procedures. For due dates and files, see the
[Homework](homework.qmd) page.
:::

---

## Submission guidelines

::: {.callout-tip appearance="minimal"}
### What to submit
- Submit a **single PDF** unless the assignment explicitly requests additional files.
- Your submission must be **clear and readable** (high-quality scan or direct PDF export).
- If code is required, include it **as instructed** (either embedded in the PDF or as a separate upload).
:::

### Good practices
- Start **each question on a new page** (recommended).
- For multi-page answers, keep pages in order and label them clearly.
- If using Gradescope, map **pages to questions** accurately.

---

## Late day policy

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
You have **6 late days** total for the semester, with a maximum of **2 late days per assignment**.

- Each late day is a **24-hour extension**.
- No credit is given after **48 hours** past the deadline.
- You are responsible for tracking your remaining late days.
:::

---

## Collaboration policy and honor code

::: {.callout-warning appearance="minimal"}
### Collaboration rules
‚úÖ **Allowed**
- Discussing concepts and high-level approaches with classmates
- Studying together and comparing understanding *without sharing written solutions*

‚ùå **Not allowed**
- Copying any part of another student‚Äôs solution
- Sharing or copying code, derivations, or calculations
- Submitting work that is not fully your own
:::

If you use any external resources (e.g., a textbook example, an online reference, or a small snippet of code),
you must **cite it clearly** in your submission.

---

## Generative AI tools policy

::: {.callout-important appearance="minimal"}
Unless explicitly permitted by the instructor for a specific homework, the use of generative AI tools for any part of your work is **not allowed** and will be treated as plagiarism.
:::

---

## Regrade policy

Regrade requests must be submitted via the course submission system (e.g., Gradescope) and must include a clear explanation.

- Deadline: within **1 week** of receiving your grade, by **11:59 PM**.
- We reserve the right to regrade the **entire** homework; your score may go **up or down**.

### Legitimate regrade requests
- Points were added incorrectly.
- The grader missed your work because it was on a different page.
- The grader claims your method fails in a specific case, but it works as implemented.

### Illegitimate regrade requests
- Disagreeing with the rubric without a grading error.
- ‚ÄúMy solution wasn‚Äôt clear, but what I meant is correct.‚Äù
